comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The Arch was the scene of a Republican ambush during the war of Independence in 1920 when two Newry men were shot dead.  This was in counterpoint to the many Newry men who had volunteered for service in the British Army for the Great War!

"Thousands of people attended the funeral at Newry Cathedral of two IRA men, Peter Shields and John O’Hare, fatally wounded in the Egyptian Arch ambush."

comment.author: 14302637@N08

comment._content: It possible that the side car under the bridge is not there by accident but is the mode of transport for the photographer Robert French.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] On the contrary I buy stamps every where I go and I've been to new places because of them and met some wonderful people. Philately gets you everywhere (vicariously)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Check out the smoke deflectors on that blue engine! Could it be our friend, the Boyne, #207?

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] Maybe but most of the vegetation that you can see, in the other photo, on this side of the bridge, would be out of frame to the right in this photo.

You can see a couple of branches of the trees to the right of this photo, poking out from behind the bridge, in the other photo, but you can't see the trees that clearly extend above the bridge and rail line in this one . 

So was other photo so much earlier than this one that the trees grew that much in between the two photos or was this photo taken first and the trees cleared from above the line before the other was taken.

The other photo looks like it was taken from that little house we can see in this photo.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Taking a slight (well fairly major) off-topic segue, but if any of you are in or close to Dublin tomorrow night, we'd love to invite you to the launch of a new exhibition in our National Photographic Archive in Temple Bar. It's called Living-Leaving and is a part of PhotoIreland Festival 2012. Launch kick-off is around 7...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 51739479@N02
comment._content:
Hello, I am very new to this site and love it. My parents emigrated from Dublin on their wedding day many years ago to England. I am by chance visiting Dublin tomorrow (from Sheffield) and, as a lover of all things Irish and photography, will certainly come to your exhibition:)

Thank you for this fascinating Flickr site and discussion group.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/bariom43] Marvellous, what good timing on your visit! There's an embarrassment of riches around Temple Bar tomorrow evening, photo-wise. The PhotoIreland Festival 2012 is launching in the Gallery of Photography. Then there's our launch in the National Photographic Archive. And there are going to be projections on the buildings around Meeting House Square later on...

And very pleased that you like our stream!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
